Calculation of Implied Volatility While it is not possible to invert the Black-Scholes Model to arrive at an implied volatility from a known option price, a Newton-Raphson search can be used to converge on the implied volatility quite quickly. We first make a guess as to the option’s implied volatility, and then use the option’s vega (sensitivity to a change in volatility) to come progressively closer to the true implied volatility. This method is illustrated in Figure B-4. Because an option’s vega is relatively linear, the method converges very quickly, usually with no more than four iterations, even with a poor first guess.
